Well, yes & no. We CAN apply L'Hospital to the definition of the derivative and we learn a tiny bit: First re-write the RightHandSide (RHS) of the definitional equation as lim_{h-->0} N(h)/D(h), where N(h) = f(h+x) - f(x) and D(h) = h. At h = 0, the quotient becomes 0/0, so let's apply L'Hospital to get: lim_{h-->0} (dN/dh)/(dD/dh). Note that dN/dh = f '(h+x) and dD/dh = 1, so the definitional equation transforms to be (df/dx)(x) = f'(0 + x)/1 = f '(x), which is true but doesn't teach us anything new except that L'Hospital's Theorem is consistent with the definition; that's not much but it's nice to see that these puzzle pieces do indeed fit together nicely. I think I might've already commented on this video, but I honestly find limits, derivatives, and integrals easier to think about in terms of d(var) being an infinitesimally small nudge. When you make the nudge small enough, it's still a nudge away from the limiting value h, but it may as well still be that limiting value. h+ε is still essentially h at the finite scale no matter how many times you add ε, but at the same time it's not h. It's h+ε. It's a value larger than h, but so infinitesimally larger than h that it may as well still be h at more finite scales for the purposes of finding the derivative or integral of a function.

But in that same line of logic, if you're finding the limit of a discontinuous function that jumps between two very different values at the limiting value, h+ε and h-ε are still so close to h that they may as well be h on the macro, finite scale, but they are also NOT equal to h or equal to each other, for that matter. One is larger than h by ε while the other is smaller than h by ε. And this infinitesimally small difference is enough to find the limit of the function's value AT h from the respective side defined by the addition or subtraction of ε. That to me is what the superscript + or - says in limits, and that to me is what the dx says in Leibniz notation or closing off the end of an integral.

I know it's not exactly the most intuitive way to think about it, but to me it somehow makes sense to think about it from this more philosophical perspective of that tiny nudge being infinitesimally small.

And in that same breath, 1/∞ = ε (which may as well just be 0 at the finite scale) and 1/ε (which may as well be 1/0 at the finite scale) = ∞. Because ε is the infinitesimal number, there is no finitely small number that can possibly describe its value. It falls into the same philosophical zone as infinity. And yet, we use such obviously non-numeric concepts as infinity and the infinitesimal as if they are numbers. But they're not. And yet the math still works and answers come right out in the wash somehow.

It's a bit of philosophy that just kinda blows my mind, and I like thinking about it anytime I use ∞ or ε in my math, even if it's only implied by the notation. :)
